commentBody:
(The normal link doesn't work.)

I liked this puzzle a lot, since it made me feel smart. It felt very hard in some sense, yet I was able to guess a lot of clue answers without any letters, which made this hard puzzle proceed pretty quickly. At times this resembled riding a pogo stick down a steep hill in a thick fog. (It did not, however, smack of juggling three flaming battery-powered chainsaws while they are turned on ‚Äî not at all.)

This was a solid puzzle.  I struggled a bit in the SW because I know nothing about Anne of Green Gables and I didn‚Äôt know the Spanish writer either.  So I just guessed INES for the latter, which helped me see COMEHITHER, and that pulled the whole corner together.  

I liked MANSPREADS, and I also liked that SARAN (clued as that‚Äôs a wrap) crossed RAPT.

TIL 'akimbo' can also be used with legs. In my narrow world, arms akimbo always meant 'with the hands on the hips.' Consequently, (still in my narrow world) only a contortionist could stand with legs akimbo, placing their feet on their hips. Who knew?
This pages link should be https://www.nytimes.com/2025/11/20/crosswords/daily-puzzle-2025-11-21.html -- not 11-20.html .
I loved this puzzle. Clever clues. Wonderful fill. A great way to start the weekend. A fantastic debut, Joyce! Thank you. Y‚Äôall have a fine Friday!
One of these days, I will remember how to spell Ado Edebiri's name without looking it up.
Great puzzle. Still laughing over 9-Down.   Like the procedure, did not see that coming.

Nice technical corner in the NE portion of this puzzle - if AYO EDEBIRI wasn‚Äôt used at least once or twice a month I‚Äôd forget how unlikely it is to hear people saying ‚ÄúYES CHEF‚Äù in a fast food diner.

CROSS / SETTO / AT REST and CESAREAN blurred the edges just enough to make this a little gamier, but HOLESINONE seems etymologically incorrect - shouldn‚Äôt that be HOLEINONES?

Anyway happy holidays, try the seven fishes.

Wow! What a great debut, and I can see some of the mentoring from Robyn Weintraub, this was a smooth but clever solve for me.
I thought I was off to the races when LEAMICHELE, ROCKETSCIENCE, COMEHITHER, and HOLESINONE were practically gimmes to me (I don‚Äôt think they are particularly easy, except LEAMICHELE if you know her, just on the same wavelength). But then I got hung up with MANSPRAWLS instead of SPREADS and the NE corner, with IRKED instead of cross, no clue about MACS and Tahoe (ok now I get it), TOLL before TOOT and once again no clue about how to remember or spell AYOEDEBIRIs last name. (I‚Äôm sorry, she‚Äôs a great actress, the show is great, she is absolutely worthy of being in a crossword, and her first name is crossword gold, but we‚Äôve had her full name 3 weeks ago, and again in April, and again now? Please, enough). Got there eventually with some help from FRAIDSO, and RIRI two days in a row (yay me! I even know how to pronounce Rihanna now). And finally, if there‚Äôs an award for crossword clue of the decade CESAREAN has got to be in the running. So thanks for a very fun solve that stretched me when I least expected it, and I look forward to more puzzles from you!
Worst Friday time for me in about 5 years. Just not on the same wavelength - I struggled mightily.
"It may bring out the kid in you" was groan worthy but brilliant. Just brilliant. Clue of the week, month and year for me.

Second attempt:

TIL that COME HITHER and "coquettish" have the same number of letters, with three of the first four in common.

Lovely puzzle!  Thanks!  Almost no common fill, and lots of clever wordplay.  Northeast stumped me for a long time until I guessed EYRE, embarrassingly.

Didn‚Äôt understand MACS until a few minutes after the gold star.  Very nice wordplay.

"It may bring out the kid in you" was amazing, the most delightful clue I can remember.  I hope it's original.

And I find that this puzzle is a from a first timer?  Wow.

I am NOT a fan of themeless, but this was a very good puzzle.  Just chewy enough for me, and bursting with "fresh fill".

Well done!

"You're the only tailor here who can fix this worn fabric?"
"Frayed sew."

("Well, you're threader than nothing.")
Excellent debut, Joyce Keller. I think we‚Äôve found clue/answer of the year with ‚ÄúIt may bring out the kid in you‚Äù and CESAREAN. Thanks!!
Someone made a typo when linking to this page. I had a real hard time getting here.

Congratulations on your very impressive debut, Ms. Keller, 

Thank you for for this tight and fun puzzle, and please count me in amongst those who are applauding the CESAREAN clue!

This was the perfect Friday! Had next to nothing on the first pass and then somehow it all fell into place beautifully. Loved the clueing... As a c-section mama the one for CESAREAN had me laughing out loud! The kid in me did not want to leave. I was in the hospital for two days (I was past due and fluid levels low) while they tried to induce labor. But no, we needed that CESAREAN to bring her out! üòÇ
Great puzzle!

Two previous commenters mentioned Taos and MACS as difficult, then said they suddenly got it.  I'm glad for them.

But can somebody please now explain it to those of us that still don't have a clue?
Lots of good stuff here, especially of course 9D. Some nice trivia also and I now know about Ayo Edebiri but I'm still bewildered by whatever the Macs/Tahoe runners connection is.
Needed three Google lookups in the NE corner.  Disappointed in myself.

I am so impressed that this is a debut! I struggled mightily with this ‚Äî one of those where you get to the bottom on your first pass and see two words filled in, and you‚Äôre not that sure about one of them.  It was tough, but with enough plugging away and making some good guesses, it gradually filled in and I finished about 4 mins under my average. Not bad. 

I feel better knowing that so many people had the same trouble that I did with ‚ÄúTahoe runners‚Äù. I had to run the alphabet (ha!) for the second letter, not remembering how to spell 11D.  

Great debut, Joyce! It felt like a perfect Friday challenge.  Well done!

Excellent debut and perfect challenge for a Friday. I too fell into the trap of entering SKIS for [Tahoe runners] before correctly entering it for [Lodge rental]. And I own several Mavs ü§¶üèº‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è I knew LEA MICHELE from her GLEE days. Super talented human. As a forlorn insomniac, my WHITENOISE machine is crucial for me to fall asleep and stay asleep. I had watched the most recent iteration of Anne of Green Gables series (Anne With an E) with my daughter, so DIANA popped right in for me! And CESAREAN clue was absolutely brilliant. 
I look forward to seeing more from you, Joyce!
Lot of deserved praise for 9D, but after filling the NW third i was pretty stuck. Walked away, and COMEHITHER opened up the rest of the grid. Feels so goid when it all cracks open at once like that.
TIL coquettish and COMEHITHER have the same number of letters
Beautiful puzzle. Congratulations Joyce! And you couldn't have picked a better mentor...
"One in a cage" is now one of my favorite clues ("Handful on the farm" being the other).

I enjoyed the solve even though it was insanely hard for me in places, beyond not only Friday but Saturday levels. In the end I broke down and looked up INES, and I also had to do an alphabet run for the crossing of the sitar composition and prized people.

I really liked many of the clues, the one for CESAREAN and RIB being prime examples.

The misdirect for the one who was totally taken by Paris was great. I actually entered Emily first, but instantly had an epiphany and changed it to HELEN. 

Knowing common crossword entries of HORAS and RIRI was a great help. I also came up with many things that initially had me stumped, like COME HITHER. Personally unknowable arcana the like of LEA MICHELE were mercifully mostly revealed by crosses.

The SW corner was what caused me most trouble. I didn't know INES and forgot DIANA. Also, I don't think of king or queen as a title, unlike Her or His Majesty, but it may simply be because I'm confusing "title" with "term of adress". Also, Polish has the word "tytu≈Ç", the equivalent of your "title", but apparently the meaning of the word is slightly different in both languages. To me, "kr√≥lowa" (queen) is just a common noun. Now for a title: "Jadwiga z Bo≈ºej ≈Çaski kr√≥lowa Polski, a tak≈ºe pani i dziedziczka ziem krakowskiej, sandomierskiej, sieradzkiej, ≈Çƒôczyckiej, kujawskiej i pomorskiej" ("Jadwiga, by the grace of God, Queen of Poland, as well as Lady and Heiress of the Lands of Krak√≥w, Sandomierz, Sieradz, ≈Åƒôczyca, Kujawy, and Pomerania").

I really wanted 50D to have something to do with agents from the CIA, MI6, CSIS, NZSIS, and ASIS doing a Busby Berkeley number.

Also, thanks to Haruki Murakami for making 39D a gimme (though I read the novel in the original, so I don‚Äôt know how it was actually translated in English).
What in the world is 22D? I had TONE but it doesn‚Äôt work with FRAIDSO.

Quite tricky indeed!
I couldn't work out CESAREAN at first because I'm so used to seeing CAESAREAN, excellent clue. MACS I would never have got, even though I'm using one. Wondered about a Tahoe marathon.

Things to keep remembering - SARAN for cling film, HORAS, DING. AYO and RIRI now in memory bank. 

New things I've learnt - HITS UP ON, GILA, ONI, INES, EBLAST, and EDIBLES = GUMMIES - does that mean vitamins? Faint memory of seeing this somewhere. Do I need to know Fanny Brice and LEA MICHELLE? 

Excellent crossword.

Overheard at the Greek costume party:
‚ÄúCome hither, Helen. I fear you look a bit flirtatious in those Cesarean cheat sheets, for there are holes in one.‚Äù

Excellent Friday puzzle!

Congratulations on a strong debut, Joyce.  Loved the crossing of COME HITHER and HEART STOPPING, which brought to mind meeting my wife. King and queen, aces, and clubs openings‚Äîare you a bridge player by any chance!

OMG yes, [It may bring out the kid in you] deserves every ounce of love it's gotten here; it's a simply world-class clue.

And credit where credit is due -- this clue was debuted in 2007 (in the New York Sun) by Patrick Blindauer.

More than just a fill-in: WHITE NOISE ‚Äì as soon as I placed this answer down, I heard it as if it were actually being produced close to me. COME HITHER ‚Äì Always loved this gorgeous phrase, haven‚Äôt thought about it in forever, and when it showed itself I glowed as I do when I run into an old friend. LEA MICHELE ‚Äì Unfamiliar with this name; when I learned about her afterward and saw how wow-worthy she is, was grateful for the TIL, and I‚Äôll remember her. Part of my learning was hearing her lovely voice here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=w7K-NtCoYIo&list=RDw7K-NtCoYIo&start_radio=1 . I also liked TIPTOED crossing SOFT, the rhyming and crossing IRAN and SARAN, and the onomatopoeic DING, TOOT, and HAHA. Most important of all was the overall feeling of loveliness in answer and clue, leaving me hopeful to experience more from you, Joyce, up the road. What a promising debut ‚Äì thank you for this, and congratulations!
You‚Äôd think I‚Äôd know better than AYOEDIBaRI, but couldn‚Äôt find it for the win. Good puzzle
This may be a NYT debut but this constructor has to have been published elsewhere, such a first class puzzle - a true work of ARE!  Well done and thanks.

This beaut brought out the kid me.

Spectacular debut.

Typical tough Friday for me, with a couple of complete unknowns (looking at you AYOEDEBIRI), but ended up being an enjoyable long workout. One puzzle find today - a Sunday from April 23, 1978 by Bert Rosenfield with the title: "Shakespeare on sports" I'll just give you a couple of theme answers without the clues. Probably not hard to guess: OMONSTROUSFAULT GENTLEPUCKCOMEHITHER LETMECLUTCHTHEE GIVEMETHEIRON YOUDIDBIDMESTEAL Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/PS?date=4/23/1978&g=29&d=A ...

CESARIAN is getting a lot of well-deserved plaudits.

But I think MANSPREADING deserves some love, as well.

ROCKET SCIENCE and SPUTNIK, nice.
And we had YURI the other day.

CESAREAN was such a spectacular clue/answer, no one has bothered about he missing "A".

I know, it's an alternate plural, but that's never stopped pitched battles before in this arena of blood.

i havent been doing this very long, but i cannot recall another puzzle whose constructors cluing wavelength was so subtly and perfectly out of phase with my own logic circuits as to cause nothing but stupid grins, smiling head shakes and internal exclamations of "huh!" from my delighted self over the course of 35 minutes or so.
absolutely perfect start to my friday.
thank you, ms keller.

gonna try again since emus seem to have grazed my first attempt...
what a delightful happenstance when the constructor and i are just sufficiently and happily logically and word-playfully out of phase that virtually the entire puzzle fills me with st-pid grins, smiley head shaking and internal "dannng!"s.
and a debut, no less.
thanks for a fine friday jaunt, ms keller.

"It may bring out the kid in you" was hilarious!
I've never heard the phrase "set to" (for "quarrel"). Is it regional?
Tricky in places. Spectacular puzzle. It‚Äôs the weekend - yay!

It's amazing how letting a stuck puzzle simmer overnight helps.  I wasn't having any luck with the NW corner and decided to retire for the evening.  The next morning I was able to come up with Ms. Michele's first name LEA, tried SLY for 19A which got me DEAL for 2D which got me MANY for 3D, which got me ADMIT for 1A, which got me ALMS for 1D, and lastly MAN for ___SPREAD at 17A.  For a puzzle for which I only got one answer on first pass, I was happy to finish just a little slower (4%) than average.
I found this to be the toughest Friday puzzle I've seen here. Just got nowhere until I revealed a number of answers. TIL "come hither" is an adjective and not a verb/noun.
If I ever watched The Bear or Wicked I'd shave 10 minutes off my average.  Who knew Rihana would get a back-to-back.

Wow, was that hard! Lots of wonderful clueing. Kicking myself at not getting 37A sooner. Somehow let 55A -- which I had no idea on --  gum up my efforts in the SW. While I did get 27D eventually, it took me time because I was locked in on the clue being an adjective applied to a person rather than a look. A real workout here; thank you, Joyce!

Fun Friday!

Or at least, that‚Äôs my opinion of the puzzle ‚Äî my own solving experience, a little less so. I had the grid full at around average Friday time‚Ä¶then proceeded to spend nearly 2x that on the last couple squares in the NE corner.

But hey, that‚Äôs just the sort of suffering that makes answers I *should* know, but haven‚Äôt managed to effectively retain, stick in my memory. A month or two back, it was BWANA and NEMEA; today it‚Äôs AYO and SETTO.

(Looking back, I always find it hard to believe how I could possibly have spent ~25 minutes puzzling over 2 or 3 final squares. In this case, it all stemmed from my bizarrely high confidence that the NYT constructor crowd‚Äôs favorite actor‚Äôs first name was either ‚ÄúAdo‚Äù or ‚ÄúIdo‚Äù, combined with my having never read Jane Eyre. That, and the wonderful clue for MACS, which I didn‚Äôt grok until the instant I finished the puzzle, right after EYRE had finally occurred to me.)
Very difficult, I think the was for the hardcore puzzlers, not for me.

I was expecting to see a lot of complaints from the proper noun folk, but it's still early.  Maybe they are late risers (or slower solvers).

I knew the answers for both LEA MICHELE and AYO EDEBIRI, but had trouble spelling both of them.  Thank God for the crosses.  And will someone cry "Natick" over the crossing of DIANA and INES?  (I don't think anything other than N will go in that square.)

And I'll join the chorus and sing the praises of "It may bring out the kid in you", but it also made me cringe and cross by legs a bit.  (Probably a good antidote to my normal MANSPREADing.)
"What 'it's not,' they say" and "One in a cage" were also delightful.

All in all, a fun puzzle.

This may have already been discussed and I‚Äôm late to the party‚Ä¶I noticed last week that my streak had been reset. I checked the calendar to see if I had missed a day and saw an uninterrupted string of gold stars, so I figured it was a temporary glitch but it still says 14 day streak instead of what it is supposed to be.  Anyone else have this issue?  Thanks!
Terribly obscure and impossibly hard. Did not enjoy this one bit.

My usual late puzzle find. A Thursday from October 20, 2016 by Alan Arbesfeld. Four 15 letter theme answers. "Supposedly, some Australian birds can participate in the America's Cup," palindromically EMUSSAILIASSUME "Peter the Great, Mother Teresa and Bob Marley, palindromically" ATSARANUNARASTA "My concealment of that footwear was so unfortunate," palindromically TOOBADIHIDABOOT "That tropical entry could not have captured first place in the fruit competition, palindromically" NOWAYAPAPAYAWON Don't recall another one like that. Must have been quite a workout to find four 15 letter strings that work as palindromes. Here's the link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=10/20/2016&g=27&d=A ...

That explains so much! I'm a bee!

(This is so much funnier expressed in dance.)

Like the puzzle, loved to see Eyre in there. Didn‚Äôt like a lot of the clues. Not difficult per se, just didn‚Äôt get much amusement out of the effort to get through them. I need to start tying to make puzzles instead of complaining about other people‚Äôs clues üòù

Excellent debut! It was difficult, but not ROCKET SCIENCE. I totally blanked on Anne's bosom friend, despite having reread Anne of Green Gables recently.

I hope to see more from Joyce Keller in the future!

For 35A ‚ÄúShe was totally taken by Paris‚Äù , ‚Äútaken‚Äù literally works of course, but the alternative I read wasn‚Äôt that Helen was in love with her captor, but that Paris was totally smitten with her.

Thanks to Joyce Keller for her fun, clever debut and constructor notes. I was not surprised to see Robyn Weintraub and Jesse Goldberg mentioned, two names that, for me, always promise excellent construction and a great solving experience. Joyce, you were schooled by the A-Team! All that was missing was Jeff Chen and David Goldberg (and a host of other fine constructors whose names could easily be added to the list).
I‚Äôm a total crossword newbie but as a mechanical engineer I can say that a cesarean WILL bring out the kid in you. Not MAY, OKAY?
I need to brush up on obscure celebrities.  Or not.

Wow! What a fabulous debut, Joyce -- and a Friday, to boot!  Congratulations on your first appearance and on constructing some very, very clever clues. I look forward to seeing more from you! 

Like many, I need to learn how to spell Ayo Edebiri without assistance as she is fast becoming a regular fixture in these puzzles. She's also a very fine actress so, hopefully, her performances will continue to far outshine her appearances in the crossword!

Happy Friday, everyone!

Whoa, that was a difficult puzzle for me! Lots of thought provoking clues. 

Also a lot to indicate the constructor might play bridge? Bid, king, queen, aces, clubs, deal, hearts, even cheats (for the less pleasing to think about side of the game)!

Nearly heart-stopping but managed to ace it...in spite of not knowing anything about The Besr...yeah, I know, I'm way behind on the latest TV stuff...  But, yowza!..great Friday challenge! Forgive the manspreading....
I junst looked up Ayo Edebiri because I ain't never wantched no Bear movie and whoh! Hottie Alert! üö®

Definitely had to focus and ponder from beginning to end but filled in fine eventually. Was confident with some early fills that were wrong and lacked confidence with others that I didn‚Äôt put it but should have because they were actually right.

That was a proper Friday! The 9D / 24A cross put me in a pickle for awhile, and was the last of the fill. Overthought the Down and insisted to myself that the A was ISAIDSO, til the forehead slap moment. Was glad to get this one done, great construction. 

Now I'm REALLY afraid for the Saturday!
Too many proper names for me to really enjoy this.

Did anyone else confidently fill in EMILY at 35A on the first pass? (Since we still can‚Äôt search the comments, this may have been mentioned.) Got a laugh from the clue wording when I realized it was HELEN. Great puzzle, and a fantastic debut from Joyce Keller! 

Like many, my favorites were C[A]ESAREAN and MANSPREADING. As a mom and a new grandmother, I am thankful to not have experienced the former, and as a frequent flyer, I am all too familiar with the latter.

Loved the puzzle, hate the reification of MANSPREADING.  I am a fairly large male, so usually the seat next to me is the last to be taken.  I do not splay my legs, nor does just about anyone I see on the El, yet even MTA ads (thankfully they haven‚Äôt made their way to Chicago) warn about this alleged scourge of manhood.

It‚Äôs not that it doesn‚Äôt happen at all, it‚Äôs making it into a symbol of ‚ÄúMAN‚Äùhood that must be eradicated.  Get back to me when ‚ÄúManages managers?‚Äù answers to KAREN, m‚Äôkay?
I don't understand how "Tahoe runners" equate to computers and therefore Macs.  Would someone explain it to me?
What a fun Friday puzzle. Congratulations on the debut!
How exactly does ‚ÄúFlirtatious‚Äù solve to ‚ÄúCOMEHITHER‚Äù?? Like I understand it‚Äôs something a flirtatious person would say, but shouldn‚Äôt an adjective solve to an adjective?

I really wanted 9D to be GOATYOGA! Great clue, regardless. 
I just learnt RIRI yesterday, so I put it to good use - funny how that works. 
Got MACS through the crosses - didn't know Tahoe was an app, and could only think of "skis", although I don't think of Tahoe as a winter resort. 
Anyone else have/want "coquettish" for 27D? Completing COMEHITHER was my final fill.

Welcome to the NY Times Friday puzzle, where you will find a host of "celebrities" no one has ever heard of, and other obscure proper nouns taking the place of clever clueing of common words. Stay tuned for Saturday when this will get even worse!

I think the nice way of saying what I want to say here is the constructor and I were "on another wavelength." Maybe even other planets, galaxies, etc. 

This was miserable for me. A total slog that BURIED me early on and I felt like I was fighting for my life with every letter I had to run through the alphabet. Many words and phrases that are not a part of my daily lexicon or that have been so deeply in the cabinets of my brain that the BEES have decided they could build a nest there. Again, just not on the same page with Ms Joyce. 

However,

I really don't have many DINGs for this one. I thought it was a really tight, well-made puzzle. I personally didn't find the clues as intuitive as some others seem to have but I thought they were clever enough. To see that this is a debut makes it extra impressive. I guess if I could offer any critique, it would be that making two of the longest entries in the puzzle celebrity names (no matter how well-known you believe them to be, dear reader) is a choice -- good or bad, your call. I think it's a bad one. 

I'm still not sure I understand MACS. Alas. 

It's a Friday. I didn't solve it without a multitude of help. (Seriously, can we rework the "Tricky Clues" section to include some of the actual tricky clues? And hi, yes I know it's subjective. Save your comment.) Onto the weekend. 

Ta-ta!
chewy! i liked it :)

LEA MICHELE? Now that's some next-level showbiz trivia. I don't even know who Fanny Brice is, but I think Streisand played her in the movie I didn't see. Filed under: things I learned from crosswords. And TOADS are symbols of fertility? That's just weird. At least the onion made sense.

When the Soviets launched Laika into orbit, the wags in the press referred to it as "Poochnik." Spoiler alert: it didn't end well for the pooch.
I found rare enjoyment in a Friday with relatively good time. Fun, thanks!
I had a look through the comments and seem to be the only one who doesn't know why Tony's cousin is OGIES. Is this an Americanism?
not to rain on anyone's parade, but haven't we had LABOR clued as "it brings out the child in you?" in a previous puzzle? it's still a fun clue, but i don't know that i'd necessarily call it original

Congratulations on a fantastic NYT debut, Ms Keller!

Like so many others, I thought the clue for CESAREAN was just brilliant. The clue for HELEN is also quite clever, though I somehow immediately realized that ‚ÄúParis‚Äù was not the city in France. 

I lost a little time with 14A trying to get Streisand to work. Ironically, one of the few NYT Broadway reviews I‚Äôve read in the past few years was of the revival of ‚ÄúFunny Girl.‚Äù But the actress who played Fanny Brice when the revival opened wasn‚Äôt LEA MICHELE, which is a new name for me.

Thanks for the slightly-crunchier-than-usual Friday. I hope you‚Äôre back here soon!
Loved this one. It put up plenty of resistance but offered some wonderful ‚Äúaha‚Äù moments as pay off. A proper work out, but achievable with my tired Friday brain. Thank you!

Brilliant! This was so much fun and on my wavelength. Perfect crunchiness. 
I was about to give up and check puzzle when the aha moment finally came...I had St. barTS, which made for some nonsensical crosses. That's when I realized that I DID actually know the Russian word! Huzzah! 
Lovely wordplay all around, and my nascent but personal best gold streak is still intact (barely. Phew!)

It brings out the kid in you... Absolutely brilliant.

The hardest English language crossword I've ever seen. So many unknowns in the clues, let alone in the answers. Even with Autocheck on I was making little headway. I finally had to google "dela cruz juana" and run the alphabet all the way to Y for the 16A 11D crossing. OK, yes, forgetting it was EYRE, not EIRE, for that governess was kind of dumb.
Trash puzzle with too many proper nouns and zero creativity

Before I go to the key to check my one iffy letter, I just want to enjoy the feeling of having completed this very challenging puzzle!  I went down the garden path, fell for red herrings, got sucked in, and looked like a sucker...  and yet some tricky clue/entry matches were improbably instantaneous.  (Lookin' at YOU, 27D!)
Tricky, tricky, tricky.

What light in yonder window breaks?  
(Gray dawn, possible light rain.  Desperately needed!  Not a drop so far this month, meaning we are shy of normal by almost 3 inches ...)
Ridiculously difficult puzzle. Think I got all of about 8 clues.

This wasn‚Äôt even fair.

COMEHITHER isn‚Äôt flirtatious

Knowing that Tahoe is a MACOSX version is inane trivia, and plenty of other clues that were not on my wavelength. GEMS, RAGA, and crossing AYO EDEBIRI whom I forfeit as soon as they appeared in this puzzle some time ago with RIRI was just ü´§ 

Not chewy, just silly. 

Thanks for the effort anyway

Quite a lovely Friday debut puzzle! More of these, please.

"It may bring out the kid in you" for CESAREAN was brilliant.

Seemed just right for a solid Friday puzzle. Got it solved without assistance, but took me 25 minutes and I had to work just about all the way through.
Akimbo means ‚Äúwith hands on hips.‚Äù I know it is something misused to mean splayed out, but I‚Äôm the daughter of an English teacher; legs akimbo is an anatomical impossibility.

My first run through had the much, much better answer to the clue "It may bring out the kid in you":  GOATMILK.

If I were Don Draper, I could turn that catch phrase into $$$millions for the world's goat farmers.

Call me if you need help with YOUR ad campaign.
Great debut!  Fun puzzle, funny clues.
La Coquetta vs. come hither https://youtu.be/6iU_9rogm4c Claudia Gonzales, formerly of iTestigo could ladysplain it quite well.
Not surprised Robin Weintraub was one of her mentors - this puzzle was fun and fresh!  And just the right trickiness for a Friday.  Thanks!

I was just not on this constructor‚Äôs wavelength even a little bit.  The ‚Äúwhat ‚Äúit‚Äôs not‚Äù, they say‚Äù is the sort of clue I absolutely despise.  It‚Äôs lazy, unclever, and way too vague.  I find the debut puzzle for a constructor is usually one I do not like at all.  I think it takes some practice.  I debated just skipping this puzzle altogether about halfway through.
Quick plug for today's Friday LA Times puzzle by Emet Ozar.  Fun, clever theme (no revealer needed), and it should have been a Thursday NYT puzzle.  :)

Am I the only one who feels like CESARIAN is missing a letter?

Took so long to think of a word that starts "CES..."
Loved this puzzle! Many of the clues made me smile when I finally got them, and the pop culture ones felt fresh and ended up being easy for me, which is not typically normal.

The ‚ÄúIt may bring out the kid in you‚Äù clue immediately made me think of Mr. Show with Bob and David. That (somewhat similar) answer would have been the right number of letters, but would have been in questionable taste.
